children.html: It‚Äôs rare for the Supreme Court to overturn precedent ‚Äî and it‚Äôs even rarer for a justice to argue against an opinion that he wrote. But that‚Äôs what Clarence Thomas did after he received gifts and family payments from a conservative legal network intent on limiting the power of federal agencies. In today‚Äôs featured story below, Julia Rock and Andrew Perez expose two decades of judicial corruption ‚Äî and explain why it could limit the government‚Äôs ability to implement climate policy, health care, and labor standards.

The Lever holds the powerful accountable through reader-supported investigative journalism that corporate media will not undertake. Join in our mission by becoming a paid supporting subscriber, and get great perks in return.

children.html:
Clarence Thomas Reversed Position After Gifts And Family Payments

By Julia Rock & Andrew Perez

children.caption: Chevron Sign (AP Photo/Alan Diaz) & Justice Clarence Thomas (AP Photo/Dr. Scott M. Lieberman)

children.text: changed his position on one of America‚Äôs most significant regulatory doctrines after his wife reportedly accepted secret payments from a shadowy conservative network pushing for the change. Thomas‚Äô shift also came while he was receiving lavish gifts from a billionaire linked to other groups criticizing the same doctrine ‚Äî which is now headed back to the high court.

deference‚Äù doctrine stipulates that the executive branch ‚Äî not the federal courts ‚Äî has the power to interpret laws passed by Congress in certain circumstances. Conservatives for years have fought to overturn the doctrine, a move that would empower legal challenges to federal agency regulations on everything from climate policy to workplace safety to overtime pay.

Thomas wrote a landmark Supreme Court opinion upholding the doctrine in 2005, but began questioning it a decade later, before eventually renouncing his past opinion in 2020 and claiming that the doctrine itself might be unconstitutional. Now, Thomas could help overturn the doctrine in a new case the high court just agreed to hear next term.

Groups within the conservative legal movement funded by Leonard Leo‚Äôs dark money network and affiliated with Thomas‚Äô billionaire benefactor Harlan Crow have organized a concerted effort in recent years to overturn
. That campaign unfolded as they delivered gifts and cash to Thomas and his family in the lead-up to his shift on the doctrine.

After revelations of the gifts and cash, Thomas‚Äô most loyal defenders have sought to deflect criticism by depicting the justice as immune from influence, insisting that he ‚Äúrefuses to compromise his principles,‚Äù as Utah Sen. and former Supreme Court clerk Mike Lee (R)
But in this situation, Thomas abandoned his own stated principles on an issue at the heart of one of the conservative movement‚Äôs most significant crusades to limit government regulation.
At issue is the 1984 Supreme Court case
Chevron U.S.A v. Natural Resources Defense Council
, brought by environmental advocates to challenge the Reagan administration‚Äôs weakening of air pollution regulations.

The Supreme Court deferred to the Environmental Protection Agency‚Äôs (EPA) interpretation of the Clean Air Act, over the protests of environmentalists. The ruling was initially seen as a win for polluters, but it created the so-called
a landmark principle in administrative law, empowering federal agencies to interpret and implement statutes.
Justice Thomas was initially a defender of the
doctrine. In 2005, he penned a decision upholding it ‚Äî over the dissent of his fellow conservative Justice Antonin Scalia.
National Cable & Telecommunications Association v. Brand X Internet Services
, addressed a federal agency‚Äôs ability to regulate cable companies under a 1934 law.
, arguing that the lower court should have applied the
doctrine to the case and deferring to the agency‚Äôs interpretation of the law.
‚ÄúIf a statute is ambiguous, and if the implementing agency's construction is reasonable,

requires a federal court to accept the agency's construction of the statute, even if the agency's reading differs from what the court believes is the best statutory interpretation,‚Äù Thomas wrote, defending both the legitimacy of the doctrine and its application in a landmark administrative law case.

children.text: But within the ensuing decade, Thomas changed course to crusade against
deference, eventually arguing that his own opinion in the 2005 case had been ill-advised.

‚ÄúIn a period spanning less than three months in the spring of 2015, Justice Thomas issued five concurring or dissenting opinions that set forth a comprehensive, originalist take on the administrative state,‚Äù one of his former clerks, Elbert Lin,
article in 2017. ‚ÄúThough Justice Thomas himself had authored one of the Court‚Äôs most significant cases affording deference to administrative agencies ‚Äî
National Cable & Telecommunications Ass‚Äôn v. Brand X Internet Services
‚Äî I argue it should come as little surprise that he would be the first to question that case if he felt the Constitution demanded it.‚Äù
One of those five opinions came in
, a 2015 case challenging the EPA‚Äôs ability to regulate power plants under the Clean Air Act. Thomas joined the conservative majority, ruling that the EPA had overstepped its authority, and wrote
deference unconstitutionally delegated power from the judiciary to the executive branch.

‚ÄúAlthough we hold today that EPA exceeded even the extremely permissive limits on agency power set by our precedents, we should be alarmed that it felt sufficiently emboldened by those precedents to make the bid for [
] deference that it did here,‚Äù Thomas wrote.
In 2020 he went even further, making the unusual move of renouncing his own decision in the 2005

That year, conservative groups were petitioning the Supreme Court to take an administrative law case involving Howard and Karen Baldwin, two movie producers who had overpaid taxes to the IRS and were trying to get their money back using an obscure argument about the postmark date of a letter.
The Baldwins lost their case at the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, which cited
precedent in ruling against the couple. The Leo-linked New Civil Liberties Alliance
to hear an appeal and overturn
$1 million in 2020 to the New Civil Liberties Alliance.
The Supreme Court voted not to take the case, with
‚ÄúAlthough I authored Brand X, ‚Äòit is never too late to ‚Äòsurrende[r] former views to a better considered position,‚Äô‚Äù Thomas

, quoting from a 1950 court decision. ‚ÄúBrand X appears to be inconsistent with the Constitution, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and traditional tools of statutory interpretation. My skepticism of Brand X begins at its foundation ‚Äî
is in serious tension with the Constitution, the [Administrative Procedures Act], and over 100 years of judicial decisions.‚Äù
Thomas‚Äô stunning reversal did not happen in a vacuum ‚Äî it happened amid a coordinated campaign by the conservative movement, led by a network that enriched him.
In the early 2010s, conservative groups began to take aim at the
through law review articles, legal challenges to regulations, and by installing justices on the court who were willing to overturn it.
as empowering the administrative state in ways they didn‚Äôt like,‚Äù Thomas Merrill, a professor at Columbia Law School,
The Federalist Society, the conservative lawyers organization where Leo is co-chair, was at the center of these efforts,
doctrine and the administrative state. The American Enterprise Institute (AEI), where Crow sits on the
of trustees, was also agitating against the
deference seems to us unsound not only for the exalted position that it confers on administrative expertise, but also for the massive political forces ‚Äî think again of
‚Äî that it unleashes at the highest levels inside the executive branch and administrative agencies,‚Äù read a
has become little more than a sedative for courts clearly anguished by the imaginative excesses of agencies, but unsure of the proper role of the judiciary in reining in those excesses.‚Äù
While conservative activists launched a judicial offensive funded by Leo‚Äôs dark money network, Leo and Crow were also moving behind the scenes to influence the justices with gifts and payments.

children.text: reported last week that Leo steered payments to Thomas‚Äô wife, Ginni, through a polling company run by Trump pollster Kellyanne Conway, and the expenses were quickly covered by Leo‚Äôs dark money network.
‚ÄúNo mention of Ginni, of course,‚Äù Leo wrote as he instructed Conway to give Ginni Thomas ‚Äúanother $25K.‚Äù
Leo, Ginni Thomas, and Crow were all involved with Liberty Central, a Tea Party-themed dark money group formed in 2010. The organization was initially funded with $500,000 from Crow, according to
on its board of directors. The organization paid
Over the past two decades, Crow has frequently provided the Thomas family with private jet and superyacht trips that Clarence Thomas failed to disclose. Crow also
owned by Thomas and allowed his mother to live there rent-free, and paid at least two years of
for Thomas‚Äô grandnephew whom the justice said he raised ‚Äúas a son.‚Äù

The largesse that flowed to Thomas was part of a larger movement to pack the court with the kinds of justices who would throw out longstanding precedents like

As President Donald Trump‚Äôs judicial adviser, Leo helped select three of the court‚Äôs six conservative justices ‚Äî while his dark money network simultaneously spent tens of millions to boost their confirmation campaigns
At least two of those justices, Neil Gorsuch and Brett Kavanaugh, were on record publicly opposing the
When Gorsuch was nominated to replace Scalia in 2017, his hostility to
in congressional questioning. As a lower court judge, Gorsuch had penned an infamous opinion
‚Äúa judge-made doctrine for the abdication of the judicial duty.‚Äù Gorsuch would not only be to the right of Scalia on
, but also could push the court‚Äôs existing conservatives to overturn the doctrine.
‚ÄúGorsuch may be the one to bring the court together on fundamental questions of administrative power that have sparked so much controversy and divisiveness in recent years,‚Äù corporate lawyer and
The next Trump appointee, Kavanaugh, also

that reining in executive branch agencies was becoming a key priority for the conservative court: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the next step in the national debate about the proper role of the courts. The administrative state is 75 years old,‚Äù he said, referring to the Administrative Procedures Act. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs become a huge, glaring issue.‚Äù

in previous cases, and declined to reveal her position on

& Administrative Deference,‚Äù which noted: ‚ÄúIf Judge Amy Coney Barrett were seated on the Supreme Court, her judicial philosophy would have a positive impact on limiting agency overregulation.‚Äù
Leo‚Äôs Network Lobbies To Kill Chevron
doctrine ‚Äî and the conservative movement‚Äôs success in stacking the court ‚Äî is more relevant than ever: Last week, justices voted to hear a case that could kill the doctrine outright.
